chapters.title: The Ever-Evolving World of Science
topics: Ethics and safety in doing science

notes.summary: This chapter introduces science as a dynamic and evolving way of understanding the natural world, with a focus on observation, curiosity, and real-life applications.
key_points: Science is a systematic process of learning about the world through observation, questioning, and experimentation.
Everyday objects and technologies such as phones, electricity, and medicines are outcomes of scientific ideas.
Good scientific work needs careful recording of data, clear communication, and honest reporting of results.
Following safety rules and respecting living beings and the environment are essential parts of doing science.

chapters.title: Exploring Substances: Acidic, Basic, Neutral
topics: Everyday examples of acids, bases, and salts
Safety while handling acidic and basic substances

notes.summary: This chapter explains acids, bases, and neutral substances, how to identify them using indicators, and how neutralisation is used in daily life.
key_points: Acids have a sour taste, bases often feel soapy, while neutral substances are neither acidic nor basic.
Indicators such as litmus, turmeric, and other natural dyes change colour in the presence of acids or bases.
In neutralisation, an acid reacts with a base to form a salt and water, often reducing the effect of both.
Neutralisation is used in real-life situations like treating ant bites, reducing soil acidity, and managing acidity in the stomach.
Strong acids and bases can be harmful and should be handled with care using proper safety measures.

notes.summary: The chapter introduces electric circuits, common circuit components, and the difference between conductors and insulators using simple activities.
key_points: An electric circuit is a closed path through which electric current can flow from a source like a cell.
Standard symbols are used to represent components such as cells, bulbs, switches, and wires in circuit diagrams.
Materials that allow current to pass through them are called conductors, while those that do not are insulators.
Everyday objects can be tested to see whether they behave as conductors or insulators in a simple circuit.
Safe use of electricity includes avoiding wet hands, damaged wires, and overloading sockets.

chapters.title: The World of Metals and Non-metals
topics: Physical properties of metals and non-metals

notes.summary: This chapter compares metals and non-metals based on their properties, reactions, and everyday uses, including the problem of corrosion.
key_points: Metals are usually hard, shiny, good conductors of heat and electricity, and can be beaten into sheets or drawn into wires.
Non-metals often appear dull, are poor conductors, and are found as solids, liquids, or gases in nature.
Exposure to air and moisture can cause some metals like iron to rust, a process known as corrosion.
Painting, galvanising, and oiling are methods used to protect metals from corrosion.
Metals and non-metals are essential in daily life, from construction and transport to fertilisers and medicines.

chapters.title: Changes Around Us: Physical and Chemical

notes.summary: The chapter helps students distinguish between physical and chemical changes with simple examples from daily life and nature.
key_points: A physical change affects the shape, size, or state of a substance but usually does not form a new substance.
A chemical change produces one or more new substances with different properties from the original materials.
Examples of chemical changes include rusting of iron, burning of paper, and setting of curd from milk.
Some changes in nature, such as the formation of clouds or decomposition of leaves, involve complex combinations of physical and chemical changes.
Many changes can be reversed, but some chemical changes are difficult or impossible to reverse easily.

chapters.title: Adolescence: A Stage of Growth and Change

notes.summary: This chapter explains the physical, emotional, and social changes during adolescence and promotes healthy and respectful attitudes.
key_points: Adolescence is the period of transition from childhood to adulthood during which the body grows rapidly and matures.
Physical changes at puberty include increase in height, change in body shape, development of secondary sexual characters, and voice changes.
Menstruation is a natural and regular process in girls and is related to reproductive health, hygiene, and nutrition.
Adolescents may experience strong emotions and peer pressure, so positive support and open communication are important.
Scientific understanding helps to challenge myths and taboos and encourages respect for self and others.

chapters.title: Heat Transfer in Nature
topics: Water cycle and seepage of water

notes.summary: The chapter describes how heat is transferred by conduction, convection, and radiation and connects these processes to natural phenomena like the water cycle.
key_points: Heat is a form of energy that flows from a hotter body to a colder body until both reach the same temperature.
In conduction, heat is transferred through solids without the movement of the material as a whole, as in a metal rod being heated at one end.
Convection involves the movement of warmer and cooler parts of a fluid, such as air or water, leading to currents.
Radiation allows heat to travel without a medium, for example from the Sun to Earth through space.
Processes like evaporation, condensation, cloud formation, rainfall, and groundwater seepage are linked to heat transfer in nature.

notes.summary: This chapter discusses different kinds of motion and shows how to measure time and speed using simple methods and instruments.
key_points: Objects can show different types of motion such as rectilinear, circular, periodic, and random motion.
Time can be measured using clocks, stopwatches, and other devices that count repeated events regularly.
Speed tells how fast an object moves and is calculated as distance travelled divided by time taken.
Understanding the relationship between distance, time, and speed helps describe and compare motions in daily life.
Simple distance–time or speed–time graphs can be used to visualise how motion changes over a period.

chapters.title: Life Processes in Animals
topics: Importance of life processes for survival

notes.summary: The chapter focuses on major life processes in animals, especially digestion, breathing, and respiration, using the human body as a key example.
key_points: Animals obtain food in different ways, but all need to break it down into simpler substances for energy and growth.
The human alimentary canal includes organs such as mouth, oesophagus, stomach, small intestine, large intestine, and anus.
Digestion involves mechanical and chemical processes, with enzymes helping to convert complex food into absorbable forms.
Breathing brings oxygen into the body and removes carbon dioxide, while respiration releases energy from food using oxygen.
Healthy nutrition, clean food and water, and good habits such as regular exercise support these life processes.

notes.summary: This chapter explains how plants carry out life processes such as making food, transporting materials, and respiring.
key_points: Plants prepare their own food through photosynthesis using carbon dioxide, water, sunlight, and chlorophyll.
Roots absorb water and minerals from the soil, and stems transport these materials to leaves and other parts.
Vessels like xylem and phloem help in the movement of water, minerals, and prepared food within the plant.
Plants also respire, taking in oxygen and releasing carbon dioxide to obtain energy from the food they produce.
By providing oxygen, food, and habitats, plants are central to sustaining life and maintaining balance in ecosystems.

chapters.title: Light: Shadows and Reflections
topics: Reflection of light and plane mirrors

notes.summary: The chapter explores how light behaves, how shadows and reflections are formed, and how simple optical devices work.
key_points: Light travels in straight lines and enables us to see objects when it enters our eyes after reflecting from them.
Shadows are formed when an opaque object blocks light, and their size and shape depend on the light source and object position.
In reflection, light bounces off a surface, with the angle of incidence equal to the angle of reflection for smooth mirrors.
Plane mirrors form virtual, upright images of objects placed in front of them.
Simple devices like periscopes and kaleidoscopes use reflection of light to produce useful or interesting effects.

chapters.title: Earth, Moon, and the Sun
topics: Shape and motions of the Earth

notes.summary: This chapter describes the relationship between the Earth, Moon, and Sun and explains phenomena such as day–night, seasons, and eclipses.
key_points: The Earth is nearly spherical and rotates about its axis while revolving around the Sun in an orbit.
Rotation of the Earth causes day and night, as different parts of the planet face towards or away from the Sun.
Revolution of the Earth along with the tilt of its axis leads to changing seasons during the year.
The Moon is Earth’s natural satellite and reflects sunlight, going through different phases as its position changes.
Solar and lunar eclipses occur when the Sun, Earth, and Moon align in specific ways, temporarily blocking light.
